channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Britain's £130 million plan to manufacture a coronavirus vaccine
item.description: Britain will get first access to a coronavirus vaccine being developed by Oxford University with pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca poised to make 30 million for the UK by September - if it works.

item.title: Woman, 19, dies after being shot outside a Lidl supermarket, sparking murder inquiry
item.description: Lancashire Police have launched a murder investigation after a 19-year-old woman, who was shot outside a Lidl in Blackburn at 3pm today, was later pronounced dead.

item.title: Female covid-19 victim, 35, is conscious and speaking after surviving record 58 days on a ventilator
item.description: The female patient is at Southampton General Hospital. The hospital's lead consultant for critical care Dr Sanjay Gupta (pictured) said she has a long recovery and 'virtually no muscle strength'.

item.title: Bill Pulllman hits back at Trump for tweeting spoof video from Independence Day
item.description: Bill Pullman, who played President Thomas J. Whitmore in Independence Day, has responded to a video tweeted by Donald Trump that shows his head over the actor's during a scene from the film.

item.title: Celtic 'to be crowned CHAMPIONS on Monday as SPL clubs agree to stop the season, relegating Hearts'
item.description: Celtic are set to be named Scottish champions for the ninth successive season after SPL clubs settled to cutting the campaign short. Celtic sit 13 points clear of Rangers, while Hearts will be relegated.

item.title: Trump doubles down and calls Obama 'grossly incompetent' after branding him and Biden 'corrupt'
item.description: Donald Trump demanded Sunday morning that former President Barack Obama and former Vice President Joe Biden face jail time for involvement in the Michael Flynn case.

item.title: Free market think tank backs Rishi Sunak's spending spree to beat coronavirus
item.description: Policy Exchange supported measures to slash expenditure following the financial crash in 2008 but has backed Mr Sunak's plans for sustained increases to public spending.

item.title: Government WON'T vary lockdown rules across the country
item.description: Speaking at the latest Downing Street press conference, Buisness secretary Alok Sharma said the government would be sticking with its national approach to the lockdown for the moment.

item.title: Aerial footage shows San Francisco's first sanctioned camping site for homeless people
item.description: Some homeless residents in San Francisco, California, can now stay in the city's first 'Safe Sleeping Village' this week

item.title: Man questioned over death of rail worker Belly Mujinga died with coronavirus after being spat on
item.description: British Transport Police officers questioned a 57-year-old man today over an incident where London Victoria rail worker, Belly Mujinga, 47, died of COVID-19 after being spat and coughed over.

item.title: Hilarious moment policeman watches young men having impromptu exercise session
item.description: As the policeman approaches a man can be heard shouting: 'High knees everyone, high knees!' The scene was captured Saturday afternoon in Birmingham.

item.title: Zoom users suffer problems as they report video-conferencing app going down
item.description: The American communications company Zoom, whose headquarters are located in California, saw some of its members experiencing audio and visual problems earlier today.

item.title: Italians take to streets ahead of bars, restaurants and hairdressers reopening tomorrow
item.description: Shops, bars, cafes, restaurants, hairdressers and museums are among business and activities that can resume Monday in Italy. Premier Giuseppe Conte said they 'must accept' increased risk.

item.title: Magnetic North Police is moving closer to Siberia, researchers reveal
item.description: Researchers from the UK and Denmark say the pole is shifting as much as 37 miles a year. Lead researcher Phil Livermore, at the University of Leeds, said: 'We've never seen anything like this before'.

item.title: Norwegian royal family don traditional dress and wave flags from balcony
item.description: King Harald V was joined by his wife Queen Sonja, his son Crown Prince Haakon, his daughter in law Crown Princess Mette-Marit and their children Princess Ingrid Alexandra and Prince Sverre Magnus

item.title: Boy, six, who was pushed from the 10th floor of the Tate Modern is walking again for the first time
item.description: Bravery, 18, from Ealing, London, threw the boy from the Tate's viewing platform on August 4 last year. The French boy 'has continued to make progress' including with his memory and speech.

item.title: Teenage girls shot in honour killing in Pakistan
item.description: Police have arrested two men on suspicion of their involvement in murdering the two girls, aged 16 and 18, at the border village on the boundary of North and South Waziristan in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

item.title: Carer dies from coronavirus with picture of her daughter and granddaughter in her hand
item.description: Care home worker Sue Cairns, 58, from Manston, Kent, died from coronavirus while holding a picture of her daughter and granddaughter after initially thinking she had beaten the virus.

item.title: Joe Wicks says he encouraged his wife Rosie to keep exercising during her pregnancy
item.description: The Body Coach, Joe Wicks, 33, revealed thqat his wife Rosie, 29, kept exercising during her recent pregnancy but took her time getting back into it as he says mothers should move forward with fitness.

item.title: Europe must 'prepare for a second deadly wave of the coronavirus', WHO director warns
item.description: Dr Hans Kluge, director for the WHO European region, said he was 'very concerned' a surge in infections would coincide with other seasonal diseases such as the flu.

item.title: Coronation Street's Shelley King, 64, shares hardship faced through filming domestic abuse
item.description: Coronation Street star Shelley Kelly has candidly discussed how acting out scenes of domestic abuse affected her.

item.title: Britain pours its first pints! Day-trippers get the beers in at the seaside
item.description: Although pubs are yet to reopen, many revellers have found their way around the rules as they headed out in the sunshine today to enjoy drinks at beach bars in Brighton.

item.title: Back to A&E: Number of people heading to hospital returns to normal
item.description: Earlier this week, NHS statistics revealed that April was the quietest month ever for A&E departments across England, as people stayed away from hospitals amid the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: UK suffers another 114 deaths from coronavirus
item.description: The latest daily figure - which bring the UK's total deaths to 34,636 - is the lowest since March 24. Business Secretary Alok Sharma confirmed the numbers today in the Downing Street briefing.

item.title: Coalition of 62 countries backs Scott Morrison's push for an independent inquiry into COVID-19
item.description: A coalition of 62 nations will support Australia's call for an independent probe into the origins of the coronavirus, infuriating China where the pandemic began.

item.title: Newcastle stars undergo coronavirus tests at makeshift testing stations at their training ground
item.description: Newcastle players have been taking coronavirus tests ahead of the squad's proposed return to training on Tuesday. United stars were spotted arriving at Darsley Park on Sunday.

item.title: Cafes, pubs and restaurants will be able to sell food and drink from street stalls within weeks
item.description: Businesses that hold a licence for outdoor seating will be given government guidance how to reopen in a limited capacity in order to bolster the hospitality industry from June 1.

item.title: Police break up 70-person rave as revellers say they are 'sick of self-isolation'
item.description: Officers in Telford said they shut down a 'mass gathering' at the Granville Country Park in Shropshire on Saturday amid the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Mother reveals son, 2, had such severe facial eczema strangers mistook it for SUNBURN
item.description: Cherise Sharp, 28, from Kent, has praised a £7.99 Oilatum cream for helping to dramatically improve her two-year-old son Roan's severe eczema.

item.title: Qatar launches world's toughest punishments with three years in jail not wearing mask
item.description: More than 30,000 people have tested positive for COVID-19 in the tiny Gulf country - 1.1 percent of the 2.75 million population - although just 15 people have died. Pictured: workers in capital Doha.

item.title: Coronavirus: Michael Gove guarantees teacher safety before U-turn
item.description: Michael Gove today guaranteed teachers and pupils will be safe when schools are reopened before swiftly backtracking as he said 'you can never eliminate risk'.

item.title: More than 300 migrants have been caught trying to get into Britain in the last 10 days
item.description: Yesterday Border Force officers have intercepted six boats carrying 90 migrants in just one day. At least 227 migrants made it to the UK over the Bank Holiday weekend.

item.title: Police department that handled Ahmaud Arbery's case faces calls to be disbanded
item.description: The Glynn County Police Department, which is handling the Ahmaud Arbery case, is facing calls to be disbanded for checkered history and scandal where an officer had sex with an informant.

item.title: Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to push ahead with annexation of occupied West Bank
item.description: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arrived wearing a mask for the swearing in of his unity government with Benny Gantz and vowed to push on with controversial plans to annex the West Bank.

item.title: Moment 'Lord of the Flies' castaway returned to island 50 years after being shipwrecked there
item.description: Tongan-born Kolo Fekitoa was just a teenager (pictured top right) when he was shipwrecked with five others on the island of Ata in 1965 for 15 months and returned there 50 years later before he died.

item.title: Hunt continues for diplomat, 52, who hasn't been seen since going for run near his home 11 days ago
item.description: Richard Morris (pictured) was last seen at 10.50am on Wednesday, May 6, in Alton. Hampshire Police have asked for dash cam footage from roads he is believed to have been running along.

item.title: Almost a third of negative coronavirus tests could be WRONG
item.description: A false negative result would mainly be the fault of incorrect swabbing, scientists say. They warn it is 'dangerous' to rely on test results as a way of handling the UK's crisis.

item.title: Coronavirus modelling by Professor Neil Ferguson is branded a mess by experts
item.description: Professor Neil Ferguson's Imperial College London computer coding that predicted half a million people could die if Britain didn't go into lockdown has been described as 'totally unreliable,' by experts.

item.title: Luxury three-house development on cliff edge plunges by £400,000 in value after massive landslip
item.description: Three new luxury homes were controversially been granted planning permission to be built on the edge of the 80ft cliff in Weymouth, Dorset.

item.title: Heathrow chief begs Government to allow flights between 'low risk' countries
item.description: Heathrow Airport chief executive John Holland-Kaye said he believes the UK should adopt a risk-based approach in order to determine where flights can travel to and from.

item.title: Video shows water pouring in to £3billion HMS Prince of Wales aircraft carrier
item.description: The Royal Navy launched an investigation after a pipe leaked on the HMS Prince of Wales, causing an ankle-high flood. The leak is said to have taken place on Friday at Portsmouth Naval Base.

item.title: Coca-Cola and Carlsberg back new all-plant drinks containers that will rot away within a year
item.description: Drinks giants Coca-Cola and Carlsberg have backed a project aiming to replace drinks containers with an all-plant material that completely decomposes within one year.

item.title: Michael Gove: More than 17,000 coronavirus contact tracers now hired
item.description: Michael Gove today revealed the Government has recruited more than 17,000 coronavirus contact tracers putting ministers on track to hit their 18,000 target.

item.title: John's apologised for leaflets encouraging people to get pizza delivered to groups in parks
item.description: Pizza giant Papa John's had to apologised after bewildered Britons received leaflets promoting the brand's pizza in the park initiative, as they observed it was against social distancing rules.

item.title: London Mayor Khan gets into the saddle as capital's workers are told to ditch public transport
item.description: Mr Khan, wearing a blue face mask and grey helmet, is pictured taking advantage of the balmy weather to cycle in London, with black Range Rover following closely behind.

item.title: Funeral directors told to expect up to 85,000 extra deaths this summer if second Covid-19 spike hits
item.description: Research carried out for the National Association of Funeral Directors suggests that even if lockdown has been successful, a second Covid-19 wave could result in 33,000 deaths across the UK.

item.title: Family make coronavirus-themed time capsule staircase during lockdown
item.description: Becky Sack, 27, from Kettering, told how she decided to use the time in lockdown to create a time capsule staircase with her family. She hopes it will delight future owners of the house.

item.title: Jermain Defoe pens heartfelt tribute to 'best friend' Bradley Lowery who would've turned nine today
item.description: A devout Sunderland fan, Bradley's hero was then Black Cats marksman Defoe and the pair quickly struck up a heartwarming relationship during the little boy's desperate fight for life.

item.title: Billionaire Christian Candy and wife Emily Compton finish £150million estate dubbed 'Candyland'
item.description: Christian Candy is said to have finished work on his home - a massive £150million estate in Surrey, now thought to be one of the most expensive private homes in the UK.

item.title: Isle of Wight mother's fury after neighbour who abducted her daughter is allowed to return
item.description: Naomi Haynes, 24, says her daughter Evie, five, is traumatised after Jennifer Ashley May-Cunningham, 33, offered her a cup of tea in a playground before locking the little girl in her flat on the Isle of Wight.

item.title: Ricky Gervais calls for celebrities to be banned from Honours List and replaced with NHS heroes
item.description: The comedian, 56, said only NHS heroes and frontline workers should instead be rewarded for their bravery during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Piers Morgan gives update on Kate Garraway's husband Derek as he battles coronavirus in ICU
item.description: The GMB presenter, 55, said that Derek Draper, 52, 'is fighting for his life' as he continues to battle coronavirus after weeks in ICU

item.title: How to make Pizza Express Leggera Padana
item.description: The British chain's pizza is topped with goat's cheese, caramelised onion, spinach, red onion, tomato and garlic oil served on a ring of dough and filled with fresh dressed salad.

item.title: China's ambassador to Israel, 58, is found dead in bed just three months into the job
item.description: Du Wei, 58, was appointed envoy in February in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic. He previously served as China's envoy to Ukraine.

item.title: Latest challenge tests your knowledge of cars - and it might just be the trickiest yet
item.description: The ultimate car emoji quiz, created by UK-based Select Car Leasing, promises to test the brains of all motor-heads. So, can you tell which car manufacturers they represent?

item.title: Eleven firefighters injured and building ablaze after massive explosion in downtown LA
item.description: Shocking footage shows the moment firefighters had to crawl down a ladder through a wall of flame as they desperately tried to escape a building following an explosion in downtown Los Angeles.

item.title: Kate Middleton's friend Sam Waley-Cohen says there will be a spike in mouth cancer due to pandemic
item.description: Sam Waley-Cohen, 38, who owns £300m worth of oral health practices, told the Sunday Telegraph , it was 'inexplicable' that dentist's offices remained closed.

item.title: Neil Gaiman travels 11,000 miles from New Zealand to get 'some space' from wife
item.description: The author, 59, took to his blog on Thursday to describe his trip halfway around the world from Auckland after he and singer Amanda Palmer hit a 'rough place' amid the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: 'They told us it wasn't contagious'
item.description: Fang Fang, 64, launched a 'forbidden' journal to capture what she heard, read and saw during the epidemic from the viewpoint of an ordinary resident at the epicentre of the crisis in Wuhan.

item.title: NatWest customers had accounts suddenly shut
item.description: In recent months, a steady trickle of NatWest customers, like Adam Siddle, pictured, have had accounts closed and contacted us for help.

item.title: Mother shares yummy Percy Pig cocktail that fans of the M&S candy can easily recreate at home
item.description: Gemma Keen, from London, shared her recipe for the delicious cocktail, which she made using Percy Pig ice-cream, tequila Rose and vodka, perfect to be enjoyed with moderation this summer.

item.title: Saudi Arabia's plans stall for futuristic £400billion megacity lit by an artificial moon
item.description: The Saudi Arabia futuristic tech-hub was set to be completed in 2025, costing an estimated £413billion. But a coronavirus-led economic slump forced the government to introduce austerity measures.

item.title: Did Agatha Christie 'borrow' the plot for her acclaimed novel?
item.description: Lucy Moffatt, a British translator, told the Observer she found an early English magazine translation of Stein Riverton's story Jernvognen, which uses the same plot device.

item.title: People share the last 'normal' picture they took on their phone before the lockdown
item.description: Taking to Twitter , Britons - and those further afield - reminisced about the times before social distancing guidelines were implemented, due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Giant 26ft basking shark spotted off Spanish beach two weeks after 13ft monster was spotted nearby
item.description: A giant 26ft basking shark was spotted off La Mamola beach on the Costa Tropical. Kayakers were warned to stay away from the creature. Another shark, at 13ft, was seen near Calahonda on May 3.

item.title: Paraglider in Berkshire celebrating release from lockdown breaks both legs in horror crash
item.description: A paraglider in Berkshire broke both his legs and suffered other injuries after crashing only yards away from the hangman's gibbet. Firefighters and a coastguard helicopter were called to help.

item.title: MAIL ON SUNDAY COMMENT
item.description: MAIL ON SUNDAY COMMENT: All the zealots of tight state control, the self-serving unions and the enthusiasts for taxing us until the pips squeak, see this epidemic as an opportunity.

item.title: Philippines ambassador calls for key worker protection after 13% of Covid-19 deaths were Filipino
item.description: The Philippines' ambassador to the UK, Antonio Lagdameo (left) has called for health workers to be 'properly' protected after 23 Filipino frontline workers have lost their lives to Covid-19.

item.title: Extension to Brexit bill could cost £378bn warns think tank as UK increases planning for no-deal
item.description: David Frost, Britain's chief negotiator, (pictured) has warned Cabinet that Brussels talks - that resume in June - are heading for collapse and said that no deal is looming.

item.title: Boris Johnson and UK's most senior civil servant Sir Mark Sedwill clash over route out of lockdown
item.description: The Prime Minister and Sir Mark are said to have had a 'tense' standoff when the plans to ease restrictions were being discussed at a meeting last week.

item.title: Joan Collins, 86, insists her iconic orgy scene in The Stud was 'tame' compared to what's on TV now
item.description: The actress noted the increase in the amount of sex and nudity shown on screens nowadays with shows such as BBC series Normal People and Fifty Shades of Grey

item.title: Spending a few seconds one metre from a colleague is equivalent to an hour two metres away
item.description: Government scientific advisors are considering telling British workers exactly how high the risk of catching the coronavirus is depending on how close they stand next to someone.

item.title: Mum gives birth at garden centre as dad uses shoelaces to tie umbilical cord
item.description: Emily Rumney, 28, from Sebastapol, near Pontypool, gave birth to baby Leah in a garden centre, after her partner James Perry, 38, acted as midwife to deliver their daughter.

item.title: Man in his 90s gets NHS treatment for being a sex addict as eight patients aged over 70 get help
item.description: A man in his 90s with an excessive sex drive was among eight patients aged over 70 treated by the NHS for their addiction to sex. 170 people have been treated in the last seven years.

item.title: Marks and Spencer launch a new recipe book - including easy ways to make curries and pasta bakes
item.description: Marks and Spencer is selling new £5 book '50 fast, fresh and easy recipes to transform family meals' in their food halls, which have stayed open amid the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Why can people get cleaners in but I'm banned from inviting mum over?
item.description: Keith Neil, professor of Epidemiology and Infectious Diseases at the University of Nottingham said it is easier to socially distance from your cleaner rather than your parents.

item.title: At last! Harry and Meghan are paying us back for Frogmore...
item.description: The pale pink peonies - flowers that Meghan has said make her 'endlessly happy' - are coming into bloom around Frogmore Cottage. Their sweet fragrance drifts across the lawns and grounds.

item.title: Man of the people? New Labour leader Sir Keir owns seven acres of land in Surrey worth up to £10m
item.description: The Labour leader acquired the property, on green belt next to the Surrey home where he grew up, in 1996, while he was working as a human rights lawyer.

item.title: Officer at the Army's secret warfare unit 'pressured veteran who reported his security blunder'
item.description: Lieutenant Colonel Rupert Burridge dropped a pile of cards with his email and phone numbers on the street. The cards were spotted in Cottesmore, Rutland, by an Army veteran.

item.title: The best UK holiday homes to celebrate the end of the coronavirus pandemic in style
item.description: Here we round-up the best properties to rent around the UK for a post-lockdown party, including an uber-modern beach house in Northern Ireland and a grand castle in Somerset.
